habitat_description:
The range of the yellow mud turtle extends from southcentral U. S. to Nebraska, southeastern Arizona to northcentral and northeastern Mexico. Isolated occurrences are reported from Iowa, Illinois, and Missouri (Conant and Collins 1991; Serb et al. 2001). In general, the habitat consists of creeks, low gradient medium sized rivers, and shallow water pools. Riparian habitats include forested wetland, herbaceous wetland, and temporary pools of main water bodies. Also found in cropland, irrigated areas, desert, grassland, shrubland, and chaparral (Natureserve.org).  

Populations are well established in quiet and slow-flowing bodies of water with mud or sand bottoms. Also in grassland and open woodland areas. The isolated populations found in Missouri, Iowa, and Illinois are found in marshes, oxbow lakes, sand prairie, scrub oak savanna, and flooded crop fields. Movement between suitable habitats is mostly restricted to distances below 200 meters (Brown and Moll 1978; Johnson 1987). Periods of inactivity take place underground on land or muddy burrows, and underwater. Eggs are laid in soft soil nearby clumps of grass within a few hundred feet of water (Cooper 1977; Iverson 1990).

Found in dense and moist forested wetland, scrub-oak savanna, marshes, and herbaceous wetland.

*Mud turtles are considered sedentary but sometimes also move many kilometers across wetland and upland habitats to find suitable nesting areas or isolated ponds or wetlands (Natureserve.org).
